title: Impact of Climate Change on Economy and Health
driving_question: How does climate change impact the economy and health, and what can be done to mitigate these effects?
short_background_context: Students model climate-related economic and health risks, predict impacts, and design mitigation strategies using interdisciplinary thinking.
pre_thinking_prompts: What ideas or thoughts come to mind?

tasks.task_text: Analyze economic impacts of climate change using data.
tasks.hint: Focus on sectors most vulnerable to climate shifts (e.g., agriculture, insurance).

tasks.task_text: Model health effects of rising temperatures.
tasks.hint: Look at heat-related illnesses, air quality impacts, and vulnerable populations.

tasks.task_text: Design a mitigation proposal balancing cost, health, and climate justice.
tasks.hint: Balance upfront costs vs. long-term savings and societal benefits.

reflection_prompt: What challenges arise when balancing economic cost, climate action, and public health?
remix_zone: Students remix by focusing on specific regions or industries most impacted by climate change.

title: Safe Internet: Ethics and Edtech
driving_question: How can we ensure a safer Internet experience for K12 students using Edtech apps?
short_background_context: Students evaluate advertising practices, data privacy, and safety benchmarks for Edtech apps through a multidisciplinary lens.
pre_thinking_prompts: What ideas or thoughts come to mind?

tasks.task_text: Research advertising types and impact on student safety.
tasks.hint: Look into behavioral advertising, targeted ads, and data collection policies.

tasks.task_text: Analyze Edtech app safety measures using statistics.
tasks.hint: Think about breach rates, data use transparency, and consent management.

tasks.task_text: Design a safer Edtech prototype using geometry and ethics.
tasks.hint: Map how user data flows through your app and safeguard key points.

reflection_prompt: How did studying Edtech safety change your perspective on digital learning tools?
remix_zone: Students remix by focusing on cyberbullying, mental health, or different tech platforms (gaming, social media).

title: Access to Healthcare: A Multidisciplinary Approach
driving_question: How can we improve access to health care in our local and global communities?
short_background_context: Students investigate health care access inequalities using data analysis, ethical argumentation, and geometric modeling for facility designs.
pre_thinking_prompts: What ideas or thoughts come to mind?

tasks.task_text: Research local healthcare access using statistics.
tasks.hint: Study patient-to-doctor ratios, insurance coverage, and travel distance.

tasks.task_text: Build an ethical argument for/against policy solutions.
tasks.hint: Focus on fairness, resource allocation, and human rights.

tasks.task_text: Design a health center layout optimizing access (geometry/algebra).
tasks.hint: Think about minimizing travel times and maximizing service coverage.

reflection_prompt: What surprised you about healthcare access? How did data change your assumptions?
remix_zone: Students remix by focusing on mental health access, telemedicine, or international health systems.

title: Understanding Mass Incarceration: A Multidisciplinary Approach
driving_question: How does mass incarceration impact our society, and what factors contribute to it?
short_background_context: Students analyze mass incarceration trends, economic costs, and justice issues, proposing reforms through interdisciplinary data and systems thinking.
pre_thinking_prompts: What ideas or thoughts come to mind?

tasks.task_text: Analyze mass incarceration data across demographics.
tasks.hint: Focus on racial, income, and geographic disparities.

tasks.task_text: Model economic cost of mass incarceration.
tasks.hint: Factor in public spending, lost wages, and generational impacts.

tasks.task_text: Design a reform policy proposal considering equity and health impacts.
tasks.hint: Balance public safety with community investment strategies.

reflection_prompt: How did studying mass incarceration affect your understanding of systemic injustice?
remix_zone: Students remix by focusing on private prisons, juvenile justice, or international justice comparisons.

title: Chocolate and Blood Pressure: A Statistical Analysis
driving_question: How can we use statistical analysis to determine the effect of different types of chocolate on blood pressure?
short_background_context: Students interpret median blood pressure reductions, analyze statistical variability, and critique conclusions based on sample distributions.
pre_thinking_prompts: What ideas or thoughts come to mind?

tasks.task_text: Determine and compare median reductions for dark and white chocolate groups.
tasks.hint: Arrange the data and find the middle value for each group.

tasks.task_text: Analyze variability and assess research claims.
tasks.hint: Variability can hide or reveal real differences between groups.

tasks.task_text: Discuss likelihood of observed differences due to random chance.
tasks.hint: Consider sample size and distribution overlap when judging significance.

reflection_prompt: How can understanding variability and randomness improve conclusions from data?
remix_zone: Students remix by exploring effects of other variables (exercise, diet, sleep) on blood pressure.
